utterance_text: I've been feeling like my wife has been on my case a lot lately about improving my health habits, but to be honest, I don't really see what the issue is. With my work schedule, it's hard to eat at home every night, so I end up grabbing dinner at places like Applebee's.
Just to make sure I understand, you're feeling a bit puzzled by your wife's concerns about your health habits?
Yeah, I feel fine. I mean, my job is physically demanding, so I'm always on the go and sweating out anything unhealthy I might eat.
That makes sense. It sounds like you're relying on your physical activity to balance out your diet.
Exactly. And yeah, I've gained a little weight, but it's not like I'm feeling bloated or uncomfortable.
Have you had any recent check-ups with your doctor that might have given you some insight into your overall health?
Actually, I did go for a physical last year, and everything came back normal.
Okay. So it sounds like you're feeling pretty confident in your current state of health?
Yeah, I am.
And what do you think is driving your wife's concerns about your health? Do you feel like she might be worrying unnecessarily?
I know she loves me and wants the best for me, but sometimes it feels like she's being a bit too cautious. When you're working hard, it's nice to treat yourself every now and then.
That makes sense. It sounds like you value those small indulgences as a way to cope with stress. Would you be open to learning more about how your diet might impact your health in the long run?
Yeah, sure.
Hi Sal, I appreciate you taking the time to come in today. How are you feeling about being here?
It's no big deal.
Your doctor referred you to me, and I'm glad you followed up on that. Can you tell me a bit more about what led her to make that referral?
Honestly, it feels like just another thing to add to my list of problems.
You've made the effort to come in today, despite feeling overwhelmed. That takes a lot of courage.
(nods)
Can you help me understand what some of the doctor's concerns were that led her to refer you?
I think it's just about making more changes – quitting smoking, cutting down on drinking, getting rid of my dog...I don't know what else is expected of me.
It sounds like there are a lot of stressors in your life right now, not just related to your asthma.
Yeah, with my wife on maternity leave and no pay, I'm the only one working. And then there's all these changes I'm supposed to make...
That does sound overwhelming. It's like you're being asked to juggle a lot of different things at once.
Exactly.
We have about 15-20 minutes together today, and I'd like to use that time to explore some of these issues with you. Would that be okay?
Yeah, I guess we have to start somewhere.
One tool we can use is an agenda-setting worksheet. It helps us identify all the different things that are going on for you.
Okay...
Just so we're clear, this isn't about making any commitments or changes right now. It's just a way to get everything out in the open.
Alright.
So if you were to list all the things that people around you are saying you need to work on or change, what would some of those things be?
Okay...
Remember, this is just about putting all the cards on the table. You're in control here.
Alright.
Let's start with your asthma.
Yeah.
What else comes to mind?
The fact that they want me to get rid of my dog, Oscar.
So your dog is a big part of this. Can you tell me more about what the doctor said regarding your dog and your asthma?
They say he's making it worse, but I don't believe it. I've had him longer than my wife...
That must be really tough to hear – being told to get rid of a pet that's so important to you.
Yeah.
It sounds like this is causing you a lot of stress right now.
Yeah, he's like my best friend.
Okay. What about your smoking? You mentioned wanting to cut down on cigarettes?
Yeah, I've been working on quitting completely.
And what about finances? Is that something that's been a concern for you lately?
Yeah, with all these appointments and taking time off work...
So it's not just the financial aspect, but also the time commitment.
Exactly.
It seems like some of these issues are interconnected. Does that make sense to you?
Yeah.
And what about your drinking? You mentioned needing to cut down on that as well.
Yeah...
Okay, so we have a lot to consider here. Is there anything else that's been weighing on your mind lately?
No, just feeling overwhelmed by all of this.
If you had to choose one or two things to focus on during our time together today, what would they be?
I think the thing with my dog has been really bothering me...and my asthma is out of control too.
Okay. Those do seem closely related.
Yeah.
Alright, let's take a closer look at those two issues and see where we can start to make some progress.

Sarah, I appreciate you taking the time to come in for your well-woman exam today. I'd like to explore some of your concerns further, particularly regarding your smoking habits. Would you be open to discussing this topic?
Yeah, I guess.
Can you tell me more about your current smoking patterns? You mentioned it had increased from once or twice a day.
Normally, I smoke in the morning, during my lunch break, and then around five or six times in the evening.
So that's approximately eight cigarettes per day. Is that correct?
Yeah.
And when did you notice an increase in your smoking habits?
Honestly, it's probably been over the past year or so.
I see. And is there a particular time of day when you tend to smoke more frequently?
Yeah, usually after my two-year-old son goes to bed. I try not to smoke around him.
That makes sense. It sounds like you're using smoking as a way to unwind in the evening.
Exactly. With my crazy schedule and night classes, it's one of the few times I have to myself.
I understand. What else do you typically do in the evenings to relax?
Um, maybe I'll have a drink or two.
Okay. Can you estimate how many drinks you have per day, and perhaps over the course of a week?
Um, maybe like two max...I don't know why you're asking me that, though. I just came here for a regular visit.

I apologize if it seems unrelated, Sarah. As your healthcare provider, my goal is to ensure you have all the resources necessary to meet your goals and maintain good health. I'm not here to tell you what to do, but rather to share information and listen to your thoughts.
Yeah, I guess.

We know that increased smoking and alcohol consumption are associated with various health concerns, including certain types of cancer and heart disease. I'd like to discuss these risks with you and explore ways to mitigate them.
Yeah...
What are your initial thoughts on this information? You mentioned earlier that you don't smoke or drink as much as others.
Well, I'm just kinda surprised because I feel like I've been trying to keep it pretty low.
It sounds like you're making a conscious effort to cut back. Can you rate your readiness to stop smoking on a scale of 0 to 10?
Um, maybe like a five.
You chose a five rather than a four. What led you to that decision?
Well, hearing about the potential health risks and being a mother...I don't want anything to happen to me.
That's understandable. Given these concerns and your goals, what steps might you consider taking to move closer to quitting smoking?
Well, I could maybe try to cut back in the evenings a little bit.
Let's quantify that goal. How many cigarettes would you aim to reduce your evening smoking by?
Well, right now, if I'm having like five or six, I could try to smoke three in the evening plus still the couple during the day.
That's a significant reduction. Would you be willing to come back in four weeks to review your progress and discuss further strategies?
Yeah, sure.
Great. We can also go over your laboratory results at that time. In the meantime, would you like some information on smoking cessation techniques?
Yeah, I think that would be very helpful.
I have a brochure here with some useful tips and distraction techniques for managing nicotine cravings.
Mm-hmm.
Additionally, I'd like to recommend that you speak with one of our counselors, Dr. Kirtley, who specializes in discussing the association between alcohol and stress.
What exactly would we be talking about?

As your healthcare provider, I want to ensure you're aware of the recommended guidelines for women's alcohol consumption. The National Guidelines suggest no more than seven drinks per week to minimize health risks.
Mm-hmm.
Since your current consumption is slightly higher, I think it would be beneficial to discuss this further with Dr. Kirtley.
I mean, I would like to talk about my stress, but I'm still not sure about the drinking thing.
That's completely understandable. Before you leave today, we'll schedule an appointment for you to see me in four weeks and also set up a meeting with Dr. Kirtley.
Okay.
Is there anything else you'd like to discuss or ask before our next appointment?
I don't think so.
It was nice meeting you, Sarah. I'll see you in a month.
Okay.
Hi Laura, thanks for coming in today. I want to make sure you're comfortable with what we'll be discussing.
Hi.

Before we begin, I'd like to give you a brief overview of our conversation. We'll explore your goals and aspirations, discuss some behaviors that might impact those goals, and see how I can support you in achieving them.
Okay.
Just to clarify, my role is not to judge or try to change you, but rather to understand your perspective and offer guidance when needed.
Alright.
Can you tell me a bit about yourself?
Well, I'm 17 years old, a senior in high school, and hoping to attend college soon.
What are some things you're looking forward to accomplishing in your life?
Getting good grades, going to college, and maybe studying pre-law.
That sounds like an exciting path. Have you considered where you might want to go for college?
I'm not sure yet, but possibly a few schools in the area or out-of-state.
Keeping your options open is great. What do you think about when it comes to studying pre-law?
It's just something that interests me, and I'd like to explore it further.
That makes sense. Can you tell me a bit more about what you enjoy doing in your free time?
I like hanging out with friends, going to parties or the mall, and attending school events.
It sounds like you value social connections and having fun. Do you have a close-knit group of friends or a larger circle?
I'd say it's moderate – not extremely popular, but not isolated either.
Being part of a community is important to you. How do your grades look right now?
They're pretty good, mostly As and Bs.
That's great to hear. Now, I want to explore some values that might be important to you. Can you take a look at this list and see which ones resonate with you?
Family, friendship, and belonging are all important to me.
What does family mean to you?
It means having people who care about me and accept me for who I am.
That's beautiful. Do you have any siblings?
Yes, one sister.
How do you think friendship fits into your life?
Having close friends is important to me, and I value being a good friend in return.
Belonging was another value that stood out to you – can you tell me more about what that means?
It's just feeling like I fit in and am accepted by others.
That makes sense. Now, let's talk about drinking. Have you ever had any experiences with alcohol?
Not much, maybe one or two drinks at most.
Can you tell me more about how alcohol fits into your social scene?
It's just something that's often present when I'm hanging out with friends or at parties.
You mentioned feeling pressure from others to drink – can you elaborate on that?
Yeah, sometimes people will ask why I'm not drinking, so it feels easier to just have a drink to fit in.
That makes sense. How often do you think you're around alcohol?
Maybe one or two weekends a month at most.
What kind of situations are you usually in when there's alcohol present?
Just hanging out with friends, parties, or small gatherings.
Have you ever been in a situation where someone was driving after drinking?
No, I've never drunk-driven and wouldn't get in a car with someone who had been drinking.
That's great to hear. What do you think about the risks associated with underage drinking?
It's definitely not something I take lightly – I know it can lead to accidents and other problems.
How does your family feel about drinking?
They don't really condone it, especially since I'm still in high school.
That makes sense. What do you think might happen if you were to stop drinking altogether?
It wouldn't be a big deal for me – I don't drink much anyway.
Looking ahead to the future, how do you see drinking fitting into your life?
Probably not at all – I have big plans and don't want anything to get in the way of achieving them.
That's great. On a scale of 1-10, how important is it for you to make some adjustments to your drinking habits?
Maybe a 5 or 6 – it's not something that's constantly on my mind, but I do think about it sometimes.
How confident are you that you could make changes if you decided to?
Pretty confident – I'm not really into the whole drinking scene anyway.
What kind of goal might be good for you to set in terms of your drinking habits?
Maybe stopping altogether, at least for now.
That sounds like a great goal. What benefits do you think you'll experience if you follow through with that?
I'll have all my senses about me, and it's better for my health.
Those are both excellent reasons. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any concerns you have?
No, I think I'm okay.
Alright, well, let's plan on meeting again in a few weeks to check in and see how things are going.
Okay, that sounds good.
And if you run into any challenges, we can work through them together.
Sounds like a plan.
Hi, how can I support you today?
Yeah, I hope so. My workplace just went smoke-free and it's really frustrating me. I plan to keep smoking, but I was wondering if there are any strategies that could help me cope with this change.
It sounds like the new policy is causing some distress for you. Can you tell me more about your concerns?
No, I'm not going to quit smoking. I enjoy it and it helps me relax. I don't see why it's a big deal.
I'd like to understand how smoking fits into your daily routine. This will help us explore ways to manage the impact of the new policy.
I smoke about half a pack a day, which isn't too bad. I've been smoking for five years, but I'm confident I could quit if I wanted to.
It seems like smoking is an important part of your life right now, and you're not ready to make any changes. However, you feel capable of quitting in the future if you choose to.
Yeah, I can quit whenever I want.
What gives you confidence that you could quit if you decided to?
Well, I just think it's something I could do if I wanted to. Although I've never tried to quit before, smoking is mostly a social thing for me – during breaks at work or after work with friends.
On a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 means you're not considering quitting and 10 means you're ready to quit, where would you place yourself?
I'd say I'm around a 2. Until the announcement at work today, quitting wasn't even on my radar.
What led you to choose a 2 instead of a 1?
I guess anything is possible. Maybe I could be convinced to quit if there were good reasons to do so. Are there any strategies or tools that might help me want to quit smoking?
There are many products and medications available that can help reduce nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms when quitting or cutting down.
That's helpful to know. I'm not ready to take action today, but it's reassuring to have options if I decide to quit in the future.
Looking back at the scale, what do you think would need to happen for you to move from a 2 to a 4 or 5?
If my friends were quitting with me, that might make a difference. But most of my friends smoke, so I don't see that happening anytime soon.
Now that your workplace is going smoke-free, it's possible some colleagues may be planning to quit as well.
That's a good point – I hadn't thought of that. Maybe there will be people at work who can support me if I decide to quit in the future.
It seems like you're looking for information and options today. I'm happy to help you explore those when you're ready.
Okay, thanks a lot.
I sense that your asthma symptoms have been particularly challenging lately, and it's essential we explore ways to manage them effectively so you can avoid future hospitalizations.

Yeah, I definitely don't want to come back here. But my doctor mentioned that Oscar, my dog, might be connected to my asthma symptoms, which seems ridiculous since I've had him for 12 years without any issues.
You sound surprised by this information. Have you reviewed the materials provided by the clinic about managing your asthma, particularly regarding pets as potential triggers?
Yeah, I have seen the materials and even read them. However, all I've been doing is taking my medication, so I don't feel like I know much about it.
It seems that you're feeling a bit uncertain about how to proceed. Can you help me understand what you mean by saying you don't know much about managing your asthma?
(no change)

I'm struck by the fact that, despite having a young baby and being concerned about your health, you've already taken significant steps towards quitting smoking. Now, it's essential to address the potential impact of your dog on your asthma.
This is all feeling a bit overwhelming. My main concern is my own health, not my baby's – he doesn't have any issues with Oscar. It's just me who has asthma.

I understand that you're worried about your own well-being, Sal. Your recent asthma attacks are concerning, and it's crucial to acknowledge the potential risks associated with severe asthma. As your healthcare provider, it's my duty to emphasize the importance of taking this seriously.

So, you're saying Oscar could be life-threatening? But I've had him for 12 years without any major issues, and now the doctor is suggesting other factors like stress or finances might be contributing to my symptoms.

Sal, it's essential to recognize that your asthma has been progressing over time. While medication can help manage your symptoms, there may come a point where it's no longer sufficient. Have you considered how this could impact your overall health and well-being?
They can just keep giving me stronger medicine, and I'll keep Oscar.

Sal, we're already at the upper limit of medication strength. If keeping Oscar is that important to you, I want to understand what that means in relation to your priorities – does his importance outweigh that of your baby or wife?

I understand your concerns, but I don't think you fully grasp my situation. I've had this dog for 12 years, and it's not something I can just get rid of without being certain it's the main cause of my symptoms.
(no change)
Good morning, Barbara. I'm Dr. Betty, one of the new GPs in the practice. How would you like me to address you?
You can call me Barbara, thank you.
Great, Barbara. I understand you usually see Dr. Brown, but he's not available today. Is that correct?
Yes, Dr. Brown is my doctor.
What brings you here today? What are your concerns about your health?
I've been having terrible trouble with my stomach and Dr. Brown hasn't been able to figure out what's wrong. I thought maybe a fresh perspective could help.
Can you tell me more about these tummy problems you're experiencing?
It's just constant discomfort, bloating, constipation, diarrhea... sometimes it feels like stabbing pains. And the smell of my gas is just awful.
That sounds incredibly distressing. How long have you been dealing with these symptoms?
I think it started after a holiday in Egypt about four years ago. I had a bad bout of sickness and diarrhea, and my stomach has never been right since then.
Have you tried any treatments or remedies for this condition?
Dr. Brown gave me some muscle relaxants at first, but they didn't help much. I've also tried various herbal remedies from the health shop, and I always carry Immodium with me just in case.
How do you decide which tablets to take on a given day?
It depends on how my stomach is feeling that day. If I'm having a bad day, I might try something different.
Have you had any tests or investigations for these symptoms?
Yes, I had a gastroscopy and barium enema early on, but they didn't find anything wrong.
How did you feel about those test results?
To be honest, I felt like Dr. Brown gave up on me after that. He said there was nothing more he could do, and I don't think he's done enough to help me.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit frustrated with the lack of progress in your treatment.
Yeah, I just feel like there must be something more they can do for me.
Can you tell me how these symptoms have affected your daily life?
Well, it's had a huge impact. I used to work full-time, but now I'm not working at all because of the discomfort and anxiety about my stomach.
That must be really tough for you. What do you miss most about your old life?
I miss my friends from work, and we used to go out together all the time. I also miss exercising and going out with my husband.
It sounds like these symptoms have really limited your social life and activities.
Yeah, it's been a big change for me.
Have you noticed any patterns or triggers that make your symptoms worse?
Actually, yes. When my husband is away on business, I tend to feel worse. And sometimes when I'm stressed or anxious, my symptoms seem to get worse too.
That's interesting. What do you think Dr. Brown thinks might be causing your symptoms?
He says it's all in my head, that it's just stress.
How do you feel about that explanation?
I don't think it can be just stress. The pain is too real for that.
Have you had any thoughts yourself about what might be causing your symptoms?
Well, sometimes I wonder if it's an infection that never cleared up, or maybe irritable bowel syndrome like my friend has.
What do you hope to get out of our conversation today?
I was hoping you could offer a fresh perspective and maybe suggest some new tests or treatments that Dr. Brown hasn't tried yet.
I understand where you're coming from, Barbara. However, based on what you've told me, I'm not sure that more tests would be the most useful approach at this point.
So you think it's all in my head too?
No, I don't think that. What I do think is that sometimes our physical symptoms can be influenced by our mental state and life circumstances.
Can you see how your symptoms might be linked to what's going on in your mind and life?
I'm not sure... I just know the pain feels real.
That's understandable. What if we tried a different approach, focusing on your daily activities and stress levels? Maybe that could help alleviate some of your symptoms.
Hmm, I suppose it couldn't hurt to try.
Would you be willing to work with me for the next few months to see if this new approach makes any difference?
Well, two or three months is a long time... what if there's something serious going on that we're missing?
I understand your concerns, Barbara. But if we do decide to try this new approach, I'll be seeing you regularly and monitoring your symptoms closely.
Okay... I suppose it couldn't hurt to try.
Great! Let's schedule a follow-up appointment for next week and go from there. Can you also make a list of the tablets you're taking so we can review them together?
Yeah, okay.
David, how are you feeling today?
I'm doing pretty well.
Would you like to take a look at this?
Yeah, check it out.
What do you think about what you see?
It looks nice. You fixed the discoloration that was there.
Yes, but I did notice some staining. What are your thoughts on what might be causing that?
The usual things - smoking, wine, coffee...
Have you considered quitting smoking at this time?
Yeah, I've thought about it, but it's not easy.
It sounds like you feel like you're being lectured by everyone to quit smoking.
Yeah, that's how it feels. I'm not an idiot; I know the risks.
I apologize if my approach came across as lecturing. That wasn't my intention.
I know you're just trying to help, but it's hard to quit.
If quitting were easy, everyone would do it. What's been your experience with smoking in the past?
I've smoked for 40 years, since I was 14. I've tried quitting a few times, but it didn't stick.
It sounds like you feel like you've tried everything and nothing has worked.
Yeah, that's right. I don't see myself changing now.
You feel like cold turkey is the only way to quit for good.
Yeah, that's what my friends who have quit say too.
It's your choice whether or not to quit smoking. Can you tell me more about what might motivate you to quit if you decided to?
Honestly, I'm not sure. Even having open-heart surgery and prostate cancer didn't make me want to quit.
You feel like those experiences should have been enough to make you want to quit.
Yeah, but they weren't.
If there was a situation that would make you decide to quit smoking, what would it be?
I don't know. Like I said, nothing seems to work for me.
You feel like quitting is something you'll have to do on your own terms.
Yeah, that's right.
Would it be okay if we discussed this again at our next visit? I'm concerned about your health.
Okay, yeah. I'm always open to listening.
As long as I don't lecture you too much?
[laughs] Yeah, just keep that in mind.
[chuckles] Don't worry, I will. You're glad to have a supportive doctor like your surgeon.
Yeah, he's good. He cares about my health.
We'll work with you wherever you are on this issue, David.
Okay, thanks doc.
Thanks for taking the time to talk about smoking today.
No problem, thanks.

It sounds like you're feeling really frustrated with your weight loss progress, despite putting in a lot of effort through exercise and other activities. Can you tell me more about what's not working for you?
I'm just having trouble losing the rest of the weight. No matter how much I try to exercise or run, it doesn't seem like anything is changing.
So, you've reached a plateau in your weight loss journey, and despite increasing your physical activity, you're not seeing the results you want on the scale?
Exactly. And I'm confused because I keep trying different exercises, but nothing seems to be working.
It sounds like you feel like you're putting in a lot of effort without getting any payoff. You're doing more exercise, but it's not translating into weight loss results that you can see on the scale?
Yes, that's exactly how I feel.
And that's really discouraging for you?
Yeah, and to make matters worse, when I try to talk about it with my family, they don't seem to care or offer any support. It feels like no one is on my side.
You're feeling a bit isolated in this struggle, like you're going through it alone without anyone to turn to for help or encouragement?
Yeah, that's how I feel.
And when you do try to reach out to your family members, they don't seem to be giving you the kind of support you need. Can you tell me more about what that's like for you?
Specifically with my dad, he doesn't just not want to support me - he actually thinks I should gain weight back.
That must be really tough for you to hear. Can you help me understand more about why your dad might think that way?
It feels like he thinks I'm trying to change who I am to fit some kind of ideal, but really I just want to be healthy and feel good in my own body.
Tell me more about what's behind his concerns. What do you think he means by that?
Hi Mary, how's your day been so far?
It's fine. Where do I need to sign?
You can sign right there. I sense that you might not be in the best mood today.
Not really.
Okay. I noticed you missed your first hour of class today. Can you tell me a bit about what happened?
Yeah, whatever. It's just the same thing every day.
It seems like that's not a big concern for you right now.
No, it's just like...I don't know why I bother.
You're wondering what the point of these visits is and why I'm asking you all these questions?
Yeah, exactly. Why are you asking me this stuff?
Would you be open to me explaining again what this program is about and how it can support you?
I guess so.
Just to clarify, my role as your caseworker is to check in with you daily, make sure you're following the rules, and get to know you better. Can that feel a bit intrusive at times?
Yeah, it feels like you just want to know my business.
I understand how it might seem that way. But I want you to know that I care about your well-being and success.
Mm-hmm.
When we first met, you mentioned wanting to get off this program as quickly as possible. Is that still a goal for you?
Yeah.
So, being here when you need to be is one way to work towards that goal.
I guess so.
Yet, it seems like you're still feeling a bit frustrated about having to do this.
Yeah. I don't know if I can promise I'll always be here.
You're concerned about being able to follow the rules and succeed in this program?
No, it's just...why do you need to know all this stuff?
It can feel overwhelming with so many people involved in your life right now, including the courts and your mom.
Mm-hmm.
And there are a lot of rules to follow. That can be tough.
Yeah, it's just too much.
Some clients have told me that they didn't realize how much they valued their freedom until it was taken away.
Right. I wish I had my freedom back.
What are some ways you think you could work towards getting your freedom back?
Like, signing the papers when you come by.
That's one step. Are there other things you could do to move closer to that goal?
Not doing what I did again so I don't have to deal with all this.
So, not wanting to go through this experience again is motivating you to make positive changes.
Yeah.
I appreciate your effort in signing the paperwork even when it feels annoying. Thank you for that.
Mm-hmm.
Before I leave today, is there anything else you'd like to add or share with me?
Not really.
Okay, well, I'll see you later today then.
All right.
All right. Bye for now.
Bye.
Hi Scott, welcome to our session today. I'm glad you're here.
Hi.
You mentioned earlier that you wanted to discuss exercising. Can you tell me more about what's been on your mind?
Yeah, I do want to talk about it.
What seems to be the challenge for you in getting back into a regular exercise routine?
Well, I just can't seem to get back in the gym. I used to work out quite a bit, and over the last couple of years, I've stopped going. I got busy, and now I'm out of the habit.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit stuck. Would it be helpful to explore some reasons why getting back into exercise is important to you?
Okay... All right...
Can you tell me which gym you currently belong to?
The Sport Fitness Center.
How far away is the gym from your house?
Just a couple of miles.
That's relatively close. Have you considered incorporating physical activity into your daily routine, such as walking or biking to the gym?
If I walked that far, I probably wouldn't even need to go to the gym, right?
While walking is great exercise, it's also important to consider other aspects of fitness, like weightlifting and strength training. Can you tell me why those things are important to you?
It-it would be important.
What motivates you to want to get back into exercising regularly? Is there a specific goal or outcome you're hoping for?
Well, I'd feel better. My clothes wouldn't be as tight. I've been growing around the middle and I'd like to get back to where I was.
It sounds like you're looking for both physical and emotional benefits from exercising. Can you tell me more about what that means to you?
I-I'm more comfortable when I feel better physically. That's the main thing.
Your health and well-being are certainly important considerations. While it's great that you want to look good, your overall health is a key priority.
Yeah... I'm not getting any younger...
You've had success with exercising in the past. What do you think would help you get back into a regular routine now?
I've gotta make time.
That's a great insight. Making time for exercise might mean adjusting your daily schedule, such as waking up earlier to fit it in.
Yeah... Okay...

When we meet next, I'd like you to experiment with getting up an hour earlier and trying to incorporate exercise into your routine. Can you bring that list of reasons why exercising is important to you?
Okay.
Great! I'll see you next week then.
Okay... Very good... Thanks.
You're welcome, Scott. Take care until next time.
Bye.
Can you share your understanding of the flu shot and its purpose?
I know the flu can be serious, but since I'm generally healthy, I don't think I need it. It seems like it's more for older adults or those with weaker immune systems.
Just to make sure I understand, you're thinking that the flu vaccine is primarily recommended for people who are more susceptible to illness?
